questions.question_text:
An administrator is leveraging existing ESXi hosts to deploy a VMware Cloud Foundation (VCF) environment.

What are two of the minimum requirements for this deployment? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AC
Answer should A&C 
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/3.10/com.vmware.vcf.planprep.doc_310/GUID-AE45ED7B-5530-4AE6-BB51-51E3D41CEDFD.html
A & D are correct, I think so...

comments.content: D is not correct. You can't add a host to VDS until the host is added to vCenter

choices.C: Hostâ€™s CPU needs to be on the Hardware Compatibility List.
choices.D: Hosts should have a configured Virtual Distributed Switch.
choices.E: Each host needs to have at least one available NIC.
choices.A: Each host needs to have at least two available NICs.
choices.B: A minimum of three VCF ready-nodes are required.

questions.question_text:
A systems administrator is tasked to deploy a management domain as part of the VMware Cloud Foundation Bring-Up process and notes the VCF components which will require at least four vCPUs.

Which VCF components have this requirement as default?

discussion.content:
B is correct, asuming vCenter's form factor is small.

vCenter sizing: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/8.0/vsphere-vcenter-upgrade/GUID-752FCA83-1A9B-499E-9C65-D5625351C0B5.html

SDDC sizing: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/4.5/vcf-management-domain-design/GUID-BBBE8493-BAE7-4EAE-BD1F-0B8AC7F44F4A.html

-YoMeroElElotero

Selected Answer: B
B is correct

comments.content: B is correct because the Medium NSX-T Manager requires 6 vCPUs for a production environment, making it suitable for use as a medium-sized NSX-T manager

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: D
it's D because the question is focused on the "VCF Management component" so NSX-T and vCenter.

Selected Answer: C
The storage policies appear as matching Kubernetes storage classes in the namespace. They are also propagated to the Tanzu Kubernetes cluster on this namespace. DevOps engineers can use the storage classes in their persistent volume claim specifications
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/8.0/vsphere-with-tanzu-installation-configuration/GUID-544286A2-A403-4CA5-9C73-8EFF261545E7.html

Correct Answer is C.

https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-vSphere/8.0/vsphere-with-tanzu-installation-configuration/GUID-544286A2-A403-4CA5-9C73-8EFF261545E7.html

fter creating storage policies, a vSphere administrator can perform the following tasks:
Assign the storage policies to the Supervisor. The storage policies configured on the Supervisor ensure that the control plane VMs, pod ephemeral disks, and container images are placed on the datastores that the policies represent.
Assign the storage policies to the vSphere Namespace. Storage policies visible to the namespace determine which datastores the namespace can access and use for persistent volumes. The storage policies appear as matching Kubernetes storage classes in the namespace. They are also propagated to the Tanzu Kubernetes cluster on this namespace. DevOps engineers can use the storage classes in their persistent volume claim specifications.

choices.C: Kubernetes storage classes in a namespace
choices.D: Kubernetes datastores in the Supervisor Cluster
choices.A: Kubernetes storage classes in the Supervisor Cluster

questions.question_text: What do VM Storage Policies match to when using vSphere with Tanzu?

An architect is designing a new vSAN cluster to be added to an existing workload domain for a customer who is on a tight budget.

What is the minimum number of hosts required for this additional cluster?

discussion.content:
Correct Answer is B.
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-Cloud-Foundation/5.0/vcf-admin/GUID-D3C55AA8-D4B9-49D4-A26F-7A713A141251.html

Verify that there are at least three hosts available in the SDDC Manager inventory. For information on commissioning hosts.

BC

Prerequisites
Configure a cluster with vSphere with Tanzu.
Create users or groups for all DevOps engineers who will access the namespace.
Create storage policies for persistent storage. Storage policies can define different types and classes of storage, for example, gold, silver, and bronze.
Create VM classes and content libraries for stand-alone VMs.
Create a content library for Tanzu Kubernetes releases for use with Tanzu Kubernetes clusters. See Creating and Managing Content Libraries for Tanzu Kubernetes releases.

Selected Answer: BC
I think too because the others answer are needed only when the Tanzu was already enabled

questions.question_text: Which two prerequisites must be met before creating a vSphere with Tanzu Namespace? (Choose two.)

choices.C: Enable a cluster with vSphere with Tanzu
choices.B: Create storage policies for persistent storage
